summary: Alaska is home to 227 federally recognized Tribes and has some of the highest crime rates. Tribes and the State of Alaska have concurrent criminal jurisdiction. In general, this means a Tribe and the state are both authorized to investigate and prosecute crimes involving tribal citizens in Alaska Native villages. Officials from the Bureau of Indian Affairs shared varying views about concurrent jurisdiction and how...
title: Tribes in Alaska: More Clarity Needed on Concurrent Criminal Jurisdiction and Funding Opportunities
